Maybe others had more ice cream or nutella that gave them a sweeter crepe, but the sourness bothered me too much. I really don't see how these can be the best crepes ever.

If you just want some crappy instant dessert for on-the-go and you're too lazy to walk elsewhere, then maybe this is for you. If this is the only crepe you've ever had, you should know there are better places out there for a few bucks more.
author: Cristal G.

description:
This place was busy but service was fast =)

Crepes were crispy, toppings were fresh, many choices to choose from, tasted gooood.

'nuff said.
author: song c.

description:
2 Stars ... BOO.  I used to like this place, but I went there tonight and got "E" which looked like strawberries, ice cream and nutella, but turns out it was just chocolate syrup.  Most other crepe places don't charge an extra $1.50 for this combo, but I learned this one the hard way.  Having gelato there is a nice option because nothing beats vanilla bean.

I'd stick to other crepe places.  I might try them again and get nutella, vanilla bean gelato and strawberries, but I'd end up paying $10 for a crepe.  No thanks.
author: James F.

description: The crepes aren't bad, but they're far from the crispy pancakes of euphoric scrumptiousness that other reviewers make them out to be.  I feel it's my civic duty to right the wrongs of you lemmings because I hate over-hyped places that fail to deliver.  To you, Sophie's Crepes, I dub thee mediocre.
author: Hoa T.

description:
KICK ASS CREPES!
I enjoyed a Strawberry Banana with added Nutella.
It's humongous. 
mMm...
author: Lynn C.

description: I used to love this place, but not anymore. Genki is my new favorite crepe spot. Sophie's crepe isn't the same anymore. The crepe is not crispy anymore as compare to Genki (located on Clement).
author: Annie Y.

description: im having w/drawals of this place. i miss the city and i miss my desserts. hoping to see you soon. Jtown is so much fun and i go to this place every trip just to have this yummy delight in my hands. vanilla ice cream, fresh strawberries, nutella and whip cream. total must have in the city when you arrive. its legit and big enough to feed you =0)
author: Patrick L.

description:
Worst crepe I ever had. We ordered a sweet crepe, one with ice cream, kiwi and whipped cream. The ice cream tasted old and freezer burned, the whipped cream fake, and the I can't even recall the kiwi.

The crepe here was so terrible, we were inspired to make our own thinking that any one with a large frying pan could do it .

And we were right:

Crepe with smoked salmon, creme fraiche and chives
Crepe with crimini mushrooms and basque shepherd's cheese
And the dessert crepe is on the stove....
author: Hoppie B.

description:
not the friendliest service, 
not the speediest of preparation, 
but they sure produce some very cute-looking, tasty crepes!
author: Melanie P.

description: Oh boy oh boy! YUMMY Crepes! I'm dreaming of them while writing about them. I've only ordered the banana and nutella crepe and it was good! The guys making the crepes are fast and amazing! Check this place out the next time you need a little snack in Japan Town.
author: Cat K.

description:
I've had better crepes... well, pretty much everywhere else I've ever had a crepe. I ordered a nutella + banana crepe, and while the bananas were sweet and the crepe itself was pleasantly crisp, there was very little nutella. So little that if I hadn't seen it made I wouldn't have known there was any in there. For the price, I expected more. 

Good if you absolutely must have a crepe the moment you walk out of Kinokuniya, but nothing special overall.
author: Erin C.

description: This is one of those places where we come back, just because.  Now my kids love love this place too.  The line can be stupid long and the price is a little high, but hey, it's city touristy.
author: Al V.

description:
Sophie's Crepes are alright, a bit over rated to other places I've been to for crepes, but still good.

I didn't really care for the savory crepes I've had here, but the sweet crepes are delicious! I always love getting strawberry banana crepes with nutella, with a little bit of ice cream and topped with whipped cream.

I do find that the crepes here tend to be smaller than most other crepe shops as well, another reason it only fetched three stars from me.
author: Mace M.

description:
This is a great place to go when you need to eat something and you don't feel like a traditional sandwich or Japanese food.

My favorite is the Chicken Salad crepe. You get tons of chunky chicken mixed with mayonnaise and some pesto. With a nice piece of lettuce, you've got the perfect lunch.

They have lots of others. I've tried the tuna salad (too juicy), the turkey (pressed, formed, tasteless), the ham & cheese (good!). The dessert crepes with ice cream are all outstanding. Try the Japanese dessert crepe for a real taste of Asia.

Their gelatos are very good. I can't remember who makes them (not Sophie's) but they're very tasty. The sundaes are really good if you're in the mood to pig out and OD on sweets.

They can be crowded, especially on the weekends, so prepare to wait. It's not so bad, they know what they're doing so stuff comes out fast. For a real treat on a sunny day, get your crepe and walk over to the plaza to enjoy it in the fresh air.
author: H O.

description: Not that impressive but a nice crepe. Great treat on the go. Our favorite was the one with egg salad (seemed weird but it was really nice).
author: Maria C.

description:
WHAT THE F***!

The crepe's here were not too bad but the Employees were complete idiots and extremely unprofessional. When I asked and happily paid for extra nutella i didn't get any. 
But get this! When i went up and asked the guy for some extra nutella, he actually said, "uh, well you can get nutella at like a costco or some stores have it"....
Obviously you have some right there! why would i take this crepe all the way to costco! ?

Also before I even ordered I went up to a different employee to ask what time they closed and he just stared at me for about 5 seconds and then started talking to his friend. So i asked again and he just shrugged his shoulders..
I don't know whats wrong with these people here but I love crepes and I wish i didn't have to deal with idiots to get one in japan town
author: Bailey S.

description: This place has a lot of variety. more of an americanized crepes. depending on what time you came, this place can be pretty crowded.  Cash only
author: David G.

description:
You wouldn't think it looking at my tiny 5'2 frame, but I am a total closet crepe whore. Crepes are definitely up there on my list of guiltiest pleasures of all time. 

Sophie's Crepes gets a meager 3 stars because I couldn't believe my eyes when I had to reach in my purse and pay $10 bucks for one single crepe. So what did this $10 bucks buy me you wonder. Well I had strawberry gelato, strawberries, nutella, and my friend added honey. Thank god my friend and I shared or else I would have had to pay $20. 

So my $10 bucks bought me my crepe, a great view of Japantown, and great people watching while waiting for my crepe. The experience was quite Euphoric of course, but the crepe was too thin and the ice cream spilt out of the crepe. This shouldn't happen to the closet crepe whore.

The bad thing about this place is that they only take cash and they have this sign that says in bold letters:

Once order placed, NO CHANGING ORDER!!!!! 

Being the closet crepe whore that I am, I would feel bad knocking this creperie so I will just say....don't forget to try Genki Crepes.
author: Cellina B.

description:
Awesome Restaurant and always a must go if you are ever in Japan town.  

I found this place a few years back and always make time to visit whenever i am in SF.  The menu has changed a little, but only to give you more options though.  

Recently I tried the 'Japanese Special w/Whipped Cream' and yes, it was amazing.  The crepe wrap itself was cooked just right, so you don't get full off of it like some other places I've been too.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Wow. Yummy! I got the strawberry crepe with green tea ice cream. It was sooo good.

But we went there in the afternoon on a Saturday, and there was a HUGE line. We had to wait 20-30 minutes for them to make our order. It was crazy. But it was worth it.

It sucks they closed down the North Beach one. And this one inside the Japan Town Center closes fairly early. 

I definitely recommend coming here to eat crepe!
author: Sam W.

description: Located in the Miyako Mall Sophie's Crepes was our post movie stop #8 on the "Eat my through SF" weekend tour. I sampled the pistachio gelato and although it wasn't bad I wouldn't call it gelato. It wasn't like the pistachio gelato I had in Italy! We ordered on savory crepe and one sweet crepe. The savory crepe we went with was the cheddar cheese and avocado crepe. It was good, but I felt it needed one more ingredient like tomatoes, hot sauce or something. The sweet crepe we ordered was nutella and strawberry. I LOVE NUTELLA and the strawberries were fresh and cold but putting them in the warm crepe made them wilt and become kind of mushy like a banana.
author: Lori K.

description: A tuna melt crepe with cheese for a little over $4? Give me some of that! Tasted so good as dessert after Sozu. I saw picture of their chocolate sundae but didn't order it. I can only imagine though how awesome that would taste...
author: Gerard Y.

description: Our crepe was tasty, but I'm not wetting myself for it like everyone else.  We ordered a crepe with Nutella and mixed fruit.  The fruit was still partially-frozen.  There were a lot of excited teenagers eating there, possibly contributing to the obesity epidemic.  I like that Sophie's has a sign posted telling you not to photograph the establishment.  Those poor crepe makers being hounded by foodie paparazzi.  Hard life.
author: Alena W.

description:
Walking crepes* so phenomenal that they are only rivaled by Genki (http://www.yelp.com/biz/genki-crepes-san-francisco#hrid:lq1Q7E5lxE9VWmzIPqptgA) in the inner Richmond. 

Expect a line, always. 

Conveniently located next to Kinokuniya Stationary, or , what I like to call "suck all the money out of my wallet in exchange for sushi-shaped erasers and snazzy pens that I lurve." DANGEROUS!

*The term "walking crepes" is one I made up and is meant to differentiate between the type of crepe you hold in a little pizza-slice-shaped cardboard holder (or napkin) and can cruise around with, versus, the type you hunker down over, such as the offerings at Ti Couz (http://www.yelp.com/biz/ZEPkIeOUs-ZFRocSwVISRA).
author: Hannah Q.

description:
It's heaven wrapped in a paper cone. My favorite combo is bananas + nutella + strawberries + vanilla ice cream. I'm not a whipped cream kind of gal. I like that the crepe itself is crispy and thin, not too thick like some other places make them.

I always feel like an 8 year old kid when I watch them make the crepes. It really is quite cool though! 

The perfect dessert after a nice hot bowl of ramen.
author: lindsay w.

description:
Maybe it was because it was so hot today, but after Sophie's Crepes I have decided that all my future crepes must have ice cream in them. Ice cream in a crepe is so ingenious I don't know why Crepes A Go Go doesn't have it. So so delicious. 

Anyway, I got a crepe with green tea paste, ice cream, and mixed fruits. It came to ~$5, and cash only, but the wait was so long, even though it was late afternoon and most people were leaving from the Cherry Blossom Festival. They said 30-40 mins, but we came back after 40 and they still weren't done. Eating time to wait time ratio is not very high, sadly enough. And the portions aren't as big as Crepes A Go Go, but it's cheaper. 

The green tea paste was more like green tea and less like green tea ice cream. Mixed fruits consisted of kiwis, bananas, and strawberries. And of course, the vanilla ice cream was the best part. :)
author: Connie C.

description:
$5.50 for that.  I saw many people in line, and I was a bit hungry after the Giants game.  For a snack, I ordered a strawberry crepe with vanilla ice and chocolate syrup.  It was very good.  It hit that sweet tooth spot that I was looking for.  Sitting here nearly 3 weeks later, I could still taste it.  Maybe I don't really taste it, but my thinks it does.  Come on, don't take things so literal.  SILLY!

If you're in the neighborhood, try it, I would go again.
author: Joey H.

description:
After my belly is full of Ramen from Fuku-Sushi.

I dragged Mr to get some Crepes. The place was packed. Ordered Strawberry & Vanilla ice cream- DELISH! 

If I have some crepes craving this is the place to go.
author: jubi l.

description:
I would like the crepes more if the boyfriend was willing to try new flavors besides strawberry and nutella. 

No, he whines, why mess with a flavor that is already good? 

Screw him. Next time I am getting a kiwi and strawberry one and we are not sharing. 

Overall, it's okay in my opinion.
author: Tara P.

description: Sophie's is what spawned my cousin and my recent obsession with crepes. We had a crepe craving and specifically drove to Japantown to get some. I had the strawberry nutella crepe and added a scoop of vanilla ice cream. I really don't get what the hype is. The strawberries weren't fresh; in fact, it looked as though they were stewed or cooked in some way. I don't know what the deal was. The crepe wasn't bad, but I've had better elsewhere. The verdict: Crepe was okay, but I wouldn't drive so far out of my way for another crepe from Sophie's any time soon.
author: Audrey T.

description: I came Japan town a few months ago with my family and we stumbled into this shop, So I ordered the Japanese crepe, which contained green tea gelato, red bean paste and a green sauce, which I forgot the name of,  and as soon as I took a good bite of it, It was like I tasted heaven. If your in japan town and want to try something extraordinary, then go to Sophie's Crepes because it's too good to pass up.
author: Michael E.

description: I will drive all the way to Japantown just to eat at Sophie's Crepes. I usually get a green tea ice cream crepe, which is simple, but it's just so delicious here. I can be pretty picky about my green tea ice cream, and Sophie's always hits the spot.
author: Kathy L.

description:
HANDS DOWN, BEST CREPE PLACE, EV-ER.

I can't stress how good these crepes are, seriously. Nutella, strawberries, whip cream and vanilla ice cream.. i've died and gone to dessert heaven.  

I think it's like 10 bucks for a crepe, depending on what you want in it, but it is so worth it. Last time I shared my crepe and it was such a mistake! Get your own, it's worth it. =]
author: Vicky C.

description:
Been to the place quite a few times. Never ordered a crepe, but I sure as hell would eat some from whoever I was with.  I mean, I never even heard of a crepe til I went to this place.  Was thinking it was some weird Japanese taco.   

But yeah, each time I'd grab a bite from someone, couldn't complain.  Finally ordered one the other day after going to Benihana's.  It was definitely the bomb.  I got one with Kiwii and Nutella.  Ate that real quick like a Tic Tac.  Could of had like at least two more.

Bring Cash. No ATM.  Unless you use public transportation.  YOu can park in the garage.  Bring small bills and try to have exact change.  I got ripped off for 50 cents from the garage cashier machine because it didn't have change, plus I was in a rush to go somewhere else.  

So yeah. Check this spot out.  Have at least 20 different kinds of Crepes...
author: Alex C.

description: Overpriced, crispy crepes are not my thing. If you don't care about money or tenderness of a crepe, then this is the place for you. They really do have creative options, especially when you're craving sweets.
author: Janet R.

description:
nutella & strawberry crepe. thin and crispy crepe, freakin' good. next time I'll make it a la mode! 

pics - http://www.yummycrave.com/2010/04/i-left-my-tummy-in-san-francisco.html
author: Monica W.

description: I love this place, too bad I don't live close enough to go very often. I remember going here as a young tween and it's still by far the best crepes I've had in the city. I have nothing bad to say about this place except that the wait has gotten longer. But it's all worth it.
author: Crystal C.

description: Now that I've had Japanese style crepes at Sophie's, I don't want to go back to the soggy, French style crepes. Smother it with Nutella and stuff it with gelato to make it a winning combo!
author: Maybelle M.

description:
these crepes are great! but when you want to add this and that, it can get pretty pricey. i've only had the sweet crepes and have not yet dared venture into the savory crepe territory.

my usual order is the mixed fruit and vanilla ice cream with chocolate sauce...add nutella...add extra whipped cream. and no, i have no shame when it comes to indulging.

the crepes themselves are generally thin. but my favorite times that i've had sophie's crepes is when the older (korean?/japanese?) lady makes them because they come out EXTRA thin and crispy.
author: Charmaine L.

description: I can't believe I haven't yelped this place yet. Began going here about 7 years ago when I was in undergrad. My absolute favorite crepe place! Japanese crepes rockkkk! Fresh fruit, ice cream, crispy crepe shell, quick service, it's awesome. I wish I lived in SF so I could eat these crepes everyday. Some people need alcohol to be happy, I just need crepes! Why won't anyone open one in the South bay? Dude, it'd do so well on Castro street. I wish I could drop outta grad school and open up a Sophie's crepes. That's how much I love this place!
author: Caroline L.

description: Checked out this joint after eating at Sapporo-ya. My friend and I split a fruit and nutella crepe with lychee ice cream filling. In hindsight I shoulda ordered my own. It was good! The nutella, fruit and ice cream all melded together into chewy sugary mashiness in my mouth. Be prepared for the lines, and the wait. But least you can see the crepe maker in action. Count up how many "mistakes" he made; crepe making is a delicate art.
author: Thomas L.

description: Love, love, love their crepes!  I like how they serve it like an ice cream cone so it was so convenient to just grab one and go.  I hate going to the city but i would definitely come back if only to satisfy my craving for sophie's crepes.
author: Janice T.

description: My chief complaint was the price: I paid $13 for two crepes. i like that it's all freshly made. even though i wish they would wear gloves and change them out frequently... i saw one girl touch the strawberries with her bare hands and who knows where those have been. The gelato that they use is just the right amount of fatty and creaminess.
author: Vicky L.

description: I've only been here once but their crepes are really one of the better I've tried, besides Genki's of course. Unforutnately a bit pricey, as with everything else in Japantown. But once in a while I'll make the trip out there.
author: Petra S.

description: This place is alright but nothing like I've had in Paris. I understand they're adding their own little twist to this French classic but c'mon. I come to Japantown to get things Japanese, not French.
author: Kolohe C.

description:
had their crepe special with green tea yogurt...came back the next day to get the same thing  : ) ... want to try nutella and strawberry with ice cream next time... soooooo GOODDDDD

the difference between Japanese crepes and American ones is the skin... the jp one is a lot thinner, perhaps the ice cream cools the crepe down so its crispy...u can watch them make the crepe at sophies...its kind of similar to what i witnessed while i was in Paris...comparable with an Asian twist

my best friend, very picky eater, miraculously  loved it too!!!
author: Evelyn C.

description: Should just follow the instruction and get Green tea gelato + green tea sauce + red bean!
author: Susan S.

description:
OVER PRICED! 

one single cup of ice cream would have cost me $3.50!! No thank you. I'd rather buy a whole gallon tub of ice cream for $3.50! 

The crepes were seriously over priced as well. I don't care how good they supposedly are....
author: Jess O.

description: The first place I ever had a crepe many years ago and when I'm in the area this is the only place I would eat a crepe.  The japanese special is my favorite.  Green tea ice cream with red bean paste and macha sauce with whipped cream! YUM!
author: Helen L.

description: Yummiest crepes ever. Every time my boyfriend and I have visited Japantown, we don't leave without getting a crepe! Heheh. I love Nutella on my crepe, it's so yummy along with vanilla ice cream. (:
author: Jessica R.

description: This is one expensive crepe but it was worth every penny.I got a green tea gelato, mixed fruits(fresh) and whip cream crepe. IT was huge, crispy and not soggy at all. It was delicious, it closed the deal right after dinner.
author: Tam T.

description: I got a crepe with strawberries, vanilla ice cream, chocolate syrup, and whipped cream.  It was okay, nothing spectacular, but good nonetheless.  I wasn't a huge fan of the crepe, it was drier than I've had, but maybe that's just the style of the crepe.  The shop was completely empty when we came here, but within minutes the tiny shop was filled with people.  My friend told me that the shop is a popular destination at night for kids and it gets really packed.  She got hers with green tea gelato and proclaimed it her favorite.
author: Matty K.

description: I saved room for dessert since we walked past this shop and I knew I wanted to come back after dinner.  I ordered the crepe with butter, cinnamon and ice cream.  As I watched them make it, they used a giant flat round grill and spread the batter in a circular motion with a flat tool for only a few seconds and then flip it over.  It looked like a super thin tire size pancake!  Then once my crepe had been flipped to cook on the other side, the cook took out a stick of butter and rubbed it over the top to melt some on the crepe.  Then he tossed my crepe over the the lady that put them together and a third person  plopped a scoop of vanilla ice cream and she sprinkled a nice course sugar & cinnamon mixture all over.  She then carefully rolled it up into a cone shape and put it in the cone shape box.  My boyfriend and I shared it as we headed back to the parking garage and it was so heavenly with a perfect amount of crispness and soft crunch from the crepe and sugar/cinnamon mixture.  Next time I will be more daring and have them add some chocolate, whipped cream and bananas.  When you see this place and how popular it is !(LOTS of patrons!) - the diet plans go right out the window!
author: Ruthie V.

description: After the yummy ramen, my childhood friend and I continued to wander the shops in Japantown.  We passed by this small shop that was filled with people and had the sweet smell of crepes.  I thought, what better way to end a great lunch than with gelato?  I was lucky to get in line when the line was not that long, and since I didn't get a crepe, I did not have to wait.  There were a myriad of choices.  I finally settled on the lychee gelato.  The lychee gelato tastes just like lychee!  And the snozzberries taste just like snozzberries!  It was good, affordable, and really hit the spot.
author: Nina P.

description:
FRESH

STRAWBERRY

AND

VANILLA

GELATO

CREPE.

Oh, and their "Black Sesame" gelato is freaking awesome BUT it's definitely an acquired taste and not suitable for all palates (I've been told, oh well, I still love it!).
author: Lisa W.

description:
I've had their savory crepes...eh...it's alright. I've had their sweet crepes and those are much better....especially if you get ice cream in it! I remember walking around J-town with my crepe in hand and chocolate and ice cream on my mouth.

Paying for the crepe is quick but waiting for it can be lloonngg, especially if you're hungry. During peak times all the tables are taken (but that doesn't really  mean anything since there are a few amount of chairs and tables) and people even spill out to the benches outside.

What enticed me to enter this place was watching the guy pour the batter onto the hot plate and evenly distributing it so that you ended up with such a thin, circular crepe! I can't even do that at home! I wonder if he had to go for some special crepe-pouring training...
author: Janel Y.

description:
This place is way too over rated. I finally tried it after craving crepes for a long time and I was disappointed. There really isn't anything too special about Sophie's Crepes. 

I ordered a green tea gelato crepe with strawberries for $6.50. The three stars are for their gelato and generous amount of strawberries. The crepe itself, although fresh and crispy, was dull. Good thing there wasn't a wait when I went.
author: Michelle F.

description:
Came here on the recommendation of my brother. He told me I *HAVE* to try this place when I go to Japantown. 

Environment- very casual. Since it's in the inside of the mall, the place itself is not very big. However, there are bench seating outside, which is totally fine. Staffs are very helpful.

Crepes- WOW! I love the crunchiness of it. Most places either have it burnt, or too soft. The crunch factor worked well with the different textures of the gelato. I ordered the strawberry+nutella crepe, with a scoop of strawberry gelato. Love the thickness of the gelato, but wasn't too easy on the spoon. My friend ordered the green tea and red bean combo gelato and he really liked it. 

Will definitely come back once I visit again. It's a bit pricier than other crepes, but it's nicely done in a way I don't regret the price. On the side note- they accept CASH ONLY!
author: Nikki Y.

description: OMG~~i love Sophie's crepe!! its the best crepe i ever had. I tried other places before but nothing compares to this place. If you go to Japantown you have to stop by here. Trust me, you'll love it.
author: kim n.

description:
Green tea & pistachio gelato!!!!!!!!!

The crepes are very good too, executed nicely. But seriously, I am in love with those 2 gelatos mixed into one large cup.
author: Alexa M.

description: Crepe felt flimsy and cracked open as I was finishing it. I had bananas, nutella, and hazelnut gelato and it came to $7.30. Ouch. It was good, but not $7 good.  I'm in Japantown a lot, but I wouldn't go out of my way to return here.  Service was just okay.
author: k h.

description:
yummy crepes! different texture than i'm used to which is usualy mushier and softer. These crepees are nice and crispy and the presentation is nice because they wrap it for you and put it in a cone type of paper wrapping.

My friend and I  shared a strawberry, vanilla ice cream, nutella, whipped cream one and then a small cup of mocha chip ice cream.

I believe their ice cream is homemade bc people were waiting for the chocolate ice cream to finish up. Their ice cream flavors seemed yummy (Pistachio, Red Bean paste, Green Tea, etc.)
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description:
This is still one of the best places to go in Japantown, hands down.  Normally, I'm not a fan of anything with red bean, but this place is the exception to the rule.  God, I want the taste of the Japantown Sundae again (red bean, green tea gelato, whip cream, and green tea sauce).  It is SO delicious.  

Oh yeah, the crepes here are pretty good too, but I don't go for that a whole lot.  I'd rather have the Sundae, oh man.
author: Ren L.

description: I love sophie's! One of their chicken savory crepe is good, but their dessert crepes are always good! I've been coming here for years. (a lot of the times when I stop by japantown)
author: Alyssa Z.

description: So I finally got the chance to come back here after how long its been and man, its still just as good. I got the letter E which includes Strawberries, chocolate syrup, vanilla ice cream and whipped cream. It was heavenly is all I gotta say. Still is definitely the best crepe spot I've been too. ;)
author: Sean E.

description: After finding out that Genki's was temporarily closed due to electricity issues(huhuhu :/ ), my friends and I decided to try Sophie's. I'm so disappointed. My friend and I ordered a tuna melt crepe and a strawberry and nutella with vanilla ice cream crepe. The crepes were so small compared to the ones at Gengki. We ended up paying $12 for two dissatisfying crepes. Plus we paid $4 for one hour street parking. Not worth it.
author: Kayla V.

description:
Whenever I go to Japantown, I stop off here for my fave crepe with whipped cream and nutella.  Pull out my lactaid pills...but so worth it.
In the Kinokuniya building, near the Kinokuniya Stationery and Gift http://www.yelp.com/biz/oml49XIewZrlbd7srw43yA?hrid=AnxKQTDLaKt7mqRVobx9eA
Easy to get to, just park in the Japantown Shopping center underground parking, take the elevator upstairs, turn left, past the Mikado Kid's store http://www.yelp.com/biz/wsUIuY6l4yTICAwrQGlSNA?hrid=qQ3Qzda6DYxiOTd5DjJQRQ and Andersens Bakery, http://www.yelp.com/biz/FTir7qcSlmO3il2rSi0urQ?hrid=tg4gWazALmycjvs44uXAwA head towards to indoor bridge to the Kinokuniya building.  Will be on your left past the Kinokuniya Book store.  http://www.yelp.com/biz/ip8_lbJ4CRoTAFsId3dl4Q?hrid=mruYqq_DhcD0FCE1I4tvPg
author: Deb N.

description:
The defining crepehouse in SF.  Their dessert crepes are what I compare all other creperies (if that's a word).  Can be a decent wait on weekends.  Their hours are not posted - one time some of my coworkers and myself showed up on a weekday and they were closed.  BOO -1 star.

I always get a stomach ache with their savory crepes.  Maybe it's the mayo that has been sitting around for a while?  LOL.
author: Dong T.

description: I do not leave Japantown without getting a crepe from here. These crepes are delicious! Banana-nutella is my favorite one. Cash only though, and it may get crowded at times.
author: Marian M.

description: A craving for Sophie's brought me to write this review.   In my opinion, the crepe has the best texture since it is not too thin, nor is it too fluffy to enjoy filled with ice cream, fresh fruit, and light whipped cream drizzled with chocolate syrup.
author: Love P.

description: WOW I already thought I reviewed this place but I didn't. Anyway the thing that really wins me over with this place (other than the size of the crepes) is the different ice cream flavors. the chocolate chip mocha is the bomb. Having that in a crepe with whipped cream is to die for. I try to avoid this place for health reasons since I don't have the best metabolism and this place is definitely not low calorie but when i know I have worked out hard and I'm in Japan Town i definitely hit this place up. This beats Genki's and crepes a gogo and all other crepe places I can possibly think of in the bay area.
author: Nir B.

description: WE LOVE SOPHIE'S!! We come here somewhat often since we have crepe-cravings normally... Actually just went this past Sunday evening and it was crazy busy. I pretty much order the same thing all the time, which is the nutella and strawberries crepe with vanilla ice cream. Just be careful if you order ice cream on your crepe, it tends to melt and drip out through the bottom! And besides that, the only downfall is that they only accept cash.  Don't count on the ATM they have in-store all the time either b/c one time we went and it was out of order. So... Yes, Sophie's I give you 2 thumbs up!
author: Dijonne M.

description: These crepes are amazing! We got the strawberry special with chocolate and ice cream, and the tuna melt, and both were delicious.
author: Andrew T.

description: I always order a gelato crepe when I go to Sophie's. There's usually a long line of folks, but the orders come out pretty quick. Oh, and remember to bring cash because it's cash only. But no worries though, if you don't have cash, the store has an ATM.
author: Frances V.

description: I've had both the mixed fruit and the red bean icecream crepe here and I have to say that the red bean icecream crepe was waaaay better. The fruit crepe has too much whipcream and was just not as good as I had expected.
author: Lulu F.

description: I normally don't go to a store specifically selling sweet stuff, but Sophie's Crepes are really delicious. I came here and got the mandarin ice cream crepe. (Ice cream costs a little extra, but it's worth it!) Of course like most crepe places, the crepes are made to order and you can even watch the guy or gal making your crepe (No pictures allowed though!).  You can sit down right inside the store or sit down in a little plaza right outside to enjoy your crepe. Take your time, they're delicious! They have "savory" crepes which consist of meats, like a sandwich. I've yet to try those, but I'll stick to the sweet crepes.
author: Tito S.

description:
I don't' know if I was addicted to the crepes, or just the accompanying massive sugarload. But when I went the other day to Japantown, I tried to resist because I was so full, but I just had to have me a crepe.

The first time, I got the special, not sure what it was called, with the green tea gelato and the red bean and some other stuff. It was good, but not up to par. The flavors didn't meld well, and seriously lacking in the red beanage. nuh-UH. 
The other day, I just had a regular crepe with black sesame gelato. LOVED the black sesame, surprisingly, and good with the crepe, but now that I reminisce, the crepe wasn't super special. After a while of eating the crepe to get to the gelato, I found myself wondering, "When am I gonna get to the gelato already!"
.
author: Meohmy H.

description: The ice cream and crepe at this place is just delicious!! I have to say this is the best crepe I've ever had! Even the crepes I ate in Kyoto & Tokyo can't compare! The texture of the crepe is crispy and delicious and the ice cream is light and just hits the spot! This is the only dessert place I would drive to SF for just to eat!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Basically every time I'm in the city, I am tempted to swing by Sophie's for a strawberry Nutella crepe... which is no small feat considering parking in J-town is pretty hard to come by (and who wants to pay for the garage when you're just going to buy a crepe?), and J-town is NOT "on the way" to the freeway. But the crepes here are a standard to set... a different standard from that of, say, a French crepe purist, but a standard nonetheless. 

The crepe itself is cooked to perfection for its use -- a little dryer and hardier than most crepes, but better-equipped for on-the-go eating (which Sophie's makes mighty convenient with their cardboard sleeve style). The crepe strikes an ideal balance between slightly crispy, but with some al dente chewiness.

Have yet to try anything else, but really, what's not to love about strawberries and Nutella? From what I can tell, they use fresh strawberries (if they're canned or frozen, at least they are devoid of that horrible syrupy goop), and they're generous with the Nutella. Even if everything else sucked, I would still go back for the strawberries and Nutella crepe. My only complaint is that the prices seem to get a little steep when you get into the ice cream and/or fresh fruit territory, but otherwise, just consider it a small price to pay for a little slice of heaven.
author: J C.

description:
I have never been a big fan of crepes, but you can smell Sophie's once you are in that section of the mall. You'll also see an entire group of people eating happily outside or watching the windows as the cooks make the crepes. 

I tried a green tea ice cream crepe - it was very simple: 1 scoop of ice cream in a big crepe wrapped up like an ice cream cone.  I was surprised at how the crepe was soft, but crispy on the edges. It was very tasty and the green tea ice cream was delicious as well.
author: Gladys C.

description:
You know somethings good  when you have to wait 20 min for your crepes. Gobble it up under 5 min. And find yourself the next week wanting more of this crap.

Could be the best crepe place in the whole of Bay area.
author: Jose S.

description:
My god this place is orgasmic. Ive only been here 2 times when I visited SF with my roomie who is a native SFer. 

Ive never had anything like it. A warm crispy yet chewy crepe with gelato all wrapped conveniently  for your eating pleasure? I had it with hazelnut gelato. Its 2 years later, and I still dream of the day I come back to SF to have this again. 

Heres a tip, get your own, you will not want to share after you take one bite. I actually wanted 2, but didnt want to look too piggish.
author: Jen T.

description:
Love the crepes - try the matcha green tea one. Also, their whipped cream is hella bomb (I never bothered to get a savory one because I always go here for dessert). Other than the staff's efficiency and their delicious crack-infused concoctions, they have a perfect CleanScores record, which ensures the flavors you taste are ... not gonna make you hurl in that creepy bathroom down the narrow hallway past the Kinokuniya stationary store whose windows are adorned with The Dog Collection posters.

http://cleanscores.com/2659/Sophie%27s+Crepes
author: Maria M.

description:
GREEN TEA ICE CREAM crepe!!!

Get SOME or get lost!!!!

and that's my succinct review.

Delicious, refreshing, creamy, crunchy, sweet.  =)
author: Richard C.

description:
I wish I could still go for a crepe beurre-sucre because Sophie's crepes look delicious... actually, according to my daughter they are!

On the bad side: looooooooooong wait time!
author: Lili G.

description:
Mmm. So good!  I have yet to adventure past the nutella, strawberry and kiwi crepe.  If I hit the gym earlier I'll add the whipped the cream topping.

Maybe one day, when I am no longer satisfied, I'll add ice cream or try something different.  Until then, I will happily munch on my "plain crepe".

Yes, lines can get long, the two hispanic workers have perfected the technique, and yes it is pricey.

Spongebob Awesomeness: 4 krabby patties with lots of nutella
author: Ronald M.

description:
Hands Down. Best crepes I've ever had.

Cheap, delicious, perfect desert after hitting up Pasta Pomodoro right next door. 

Strawberries, NUTELLA & vanilla ice cream. A MUST.
author: Steph W.

description:
This place probably has the best dessert crepes in the city. The crepe skin itself is really good, but when you add the ice cream, whip cream, fruits, and chocolate it's divine! Its also fun to watch them make the crepes while you are waiting for your order.

If you do eat here I recommend ordering from the menu at the cashier's table. There's a menu with "specials" on it, they are generally cheaper and good for first timers. 

The only reason I am giving them a 4 is because it is a little pricey for me.
author: Jay L.

description:
Best Dessert Crepes is Sf!
Avoid touristy times, they can get pretty packed.
author: Dana O.

description: After trying this place, genkis and the other place around the corner.. This place takes the cake. While the other crepe place makes cute faces on the top, this place has a lot more variety not to mention a line that will allow you to choose your selection during your wait. I find it very reasonable in price and the ice cream, excuse me, gelato finds it way all the down to the last bite. I usually don't finish a whole crepe but the cookies and creams gelato crepe allows me to break that mold and savor each bite to the end.. After re reading this, I will be reviewing a 24 fitness next.
author: Deanna W.

description: I love these crepes.  The fruit is fresh and the crepe skin is just right.  I love coming to this place for dessert.  Just beware, at times the line for this place can get pretty long.
author: Praise C.

description:
Absolute love! Sophie's crepes are always crunchy and their gelato is just so smooth! I always or usually get a crepe with chocolate gelato and bananas. And for the price I'm paying, they make it super yummy! I always end up craving some more afterwards. 

This is one of the MUST GO places at Japantown! Seriously, don't even think about skipping this place. :D
author: Jessica T.

description: Dozens of crepes for $5.50 wrapped up like an ice cream cone; Strawberries, vanilla ice cream and whipped cream drizzled in chocolate, and bananas with whipped cream.  So delicious!
author: Cathaleya C.

description: Yum! Yum! Yum!  The #17 "Japanese" is what I always order.  Green tea gelato with azuki beans and matcha sauce.  DELISH!!!!  I really like how the crepe is served like a cone and that the crepe holds up well with all the filling inside.  Don't let the crowd deter you from purchasing a crepe at Sophie's.  You won't regret it.
author: D B.

description: That is all I have got to say. It is good if you are feeding a crowd, everyone can pick out what they want and there is plenty of seating. "nuff said.
author: joan b.

description: I can't believe I haven't written this review before! I don't find myself in Japantown Center often, but I confess that I do sometimes make excuses to go just to get a crepe from Sophie's. These crepes are some of the best I've had outside of France. The crepe is always perfectly made: thin, soft, and sweet. And the gelato and nutella and fruit are fabulous! It's the perfect combination! My other go-to place for crepes in Genki because it's more conveniently located to my house. Genki does have decent crepes, but Sophie's crepes are far, far superior to those at Genki, so you'll have to make the trek to Japantown.
author: Amy B.

description:
Delicious, absolutely delicious. 

You truly cannot go wrong with serving fresh fruit in crepes and whipped cream. But then again i've only tried the #13 Mixed Fruit. From what i know and see while i'm at Sopies Crepes, i love it.

I give it three stars, and here's my three reasons why:
1.  Service: Fast, moderately friendly
2. Taste: Delicious, so damn good.
3. Price: Decent, what you would expect from Japantown.

I APPROVE!
author: Eric T.

description: Ok I was born and raised in SF and hung out in Japan Town all the time, but I never had the urge to try Sophie's Crepes till yesterday.  Oh my goodness, didn't realize what I was missing out on all these years!!! Thanks Cam for taking me :0)
author: Jamie H.

description: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place! I've always wanted to try Sophie's crepes, but the line's always hella long! Thus the reason I've only tried it recently. YUM YUM YUM! I got my personal favorite of nutella plus fruits. I can't really recall which fruits I had in my crepes - either strawberries or bananas. But then, either way, the crepes tasted sooooo good...T___T The crepes itself wasn't too crispy not was it too soft (I've had some that are so soft, I don't think they're cooked). And the crepes smells really wonderful - sweet smelling and tasting and creamy, ah, just perfect. Anyhow, my point is, try Sophie's crepes, you won't regret!!!
author: Melissa S.

description:
I kept hearing this place was good. That was all I heard from my boyfriend for a while.

"you've never had a crepe until you've had sophies crepes"

Well I had one finally after a big dinner at Juban and seriously, IT"S THE BEST EFFING CREPE I'VE EVER HAD! They serve it like an ice cream cone kinda with a spoon and it's amazing. Like seriously. I'm so glad I don't live near or else i'd need to become bffs with my gym.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I LOVE this place. But I think right now it's not as good as before....Since it gets more popular nowadays, the wait for the crepe is getting longer and longer @__@ 

But I still think the quality of the crepe is good. It reminds me of what I have in Japan. =D I have been a fan of this place in the past 6 years. It's awesome. But it's getting more and more expensive nowadays. =\ I can't blame the business too much b/c people keep on coming back. 

My all time favorite is strawberry with nutella. i'm not a big fan of adding whipping cream. but that's just my taste. And I stop adding ice-cream to my crepe just b/c it's getting too expensive if you get a geleto instead of regular plain vanilla ice-cream. =\
author: Michelle L.

description: Heard all the wonderful tasty comments bout this place. So on my day off me, my bf and our 2 lovely dogs took a trip to SF and try out Sophie's crepes. It was the best crepes ever. I got the japanese crepes (green tea ice cream with red beans and green tea sauce) He got the ham, lettuce, and something else but all in all both was astounding.
author: Vanny L.

description: BEST CREPES EVER!!  i always get the dessert ones and they are FILLED with lovely ice cream and fruit.  the crepe itself is also perfectly crispy!  I also like that they shaped the crepe like a cone so i can eat while i walk!
author: Kristen T.

description: Even though this place does not really compare to my Ticouz on Mission...any crepes that could be eaten like Ice Cream style is always a plus in my book! I got just a plain crepe with green tea ice cream and it was the perfect dessert after all that meat I consumed at Juban. hahhahhahah....always try to remember to leave a little room for dessert :) I like the fact that its thin and crispy. I guess I have to come back here at least once a week to try out all the combos that they have on the menu. now, I just have to figure out how to alternate between my cupcakes, cream puffs, and crepes....thankgoodness there's 7 days out of a week!
author: Rika K.

description:
When I was in Japan with my mom, we used to buy crepes from the street vendors. and since fruit is ridiculously expensive on an island with zero land for growing anything, there are about five measly slices of banana in each crepe. And loads of whipped cream. So my mother and I fought over every bit of banana. After the five millionth rendition of this, i'd tell her to get her own, and she'd be like, "No! I couldn't possibly finish it!" and snatch mine back and pretty much scarf down all of my precious banana slices. 

I don't really know how that was related. But when we came back home and found Sophie's Crepes, which puts plenty of banana in its crepes along with strawberries and whipped cream and nutella and chocolate and ice cream and whatever else you want to stick in there, and actually pays attention to your directions, well, nothing changed. We still fight over the banana slices. But at least there's more to fight over.

I've tried the gelato a total of once, which was when they ran out of bananas. it was good. but nothing compared to the crepes.
author: Amy C.

description:
This crepe place is to die for. I freaking love it.

In the words of Rachael Ray....Yummo!!
author: Bianca B.

description:
the Japanese crepe is DELICIOUS!

I love the red bean gelato too!

Prices are okay.  About $4+ for the crepe and $2.75 for a single scoop of gelato (throw in an extra $.50 for a double scoop).  

And don't bring your camera to take pictures of them making the crepes haha
author: Michelle W.

description:
One of the better creperies in the City...the sweet crepes they offer contain real fruit (it's not such a big thing until one realizes back in Paris that the fruit crepes they sell only contain fruit jam/jelly which is rather gross and soggy).  I haven't eaten the savory stuff yet, so I can't review much on that...but the dozens of toppings...really makes for this place as a must stop when hitting the Jtown circuit. I'm especially partial to the mandarin orange concoction plus I always have them put in mango gelato instead of their standard ice cream...it's soo good.

Be prepared to watch in a daze at the front window as they prepare the crepes on the heated round turntable.  It's rather hypnotizing as there's always a crowd that stands in front like sheep to ooh and ahh over the fresh batter...(I'm one of them...hey...beats spending more moolah at Kinokuniya ^_^).
author: Pauline L.

description:
So i have this thing...every time after I eat Japanese food...I get a craving for ice cream...don't ask me why. I'm weird.

After yet another successful scarfing of Japanese food, I started to whine about wanting ice cream. My man's bro said we had to go to Sophie's Crepes.

The menu was so vast that I had no idea what to pick. 
my man: "mary are you ready?"
me: "uhhhh"
my man's bro: "oh you can design your own creepy"
me: "maybe i'll get the....uhhhh"

I finally ordered their chocolate sundae. I wasn't feeling crepes at the moment although it smelled AWESOME.  But as you all should know by now...I always go for the chocolate. It was good. oh so good. although I must admit that I may have actually overdosed on chocolate this time. 

Next time I will definately have to try some crepe with gelato.
author: Mary L.

description:
Something kind of scary about Sophie's: they will go completely aggro if you try to take a photo.  Why?

I speculate it is because they are in an ongoing trade war with Genki, which also makes crepes.  They too will flip out if you produce a camera from your person.

Try it, actually.  It can be pretty entertaining.

Crepes are good though.  I like the green tea one with the yomogi and adzuki bean.
author: Brian D.

description:
One of the highlights in SF's Japantown. Everytime I go to Japantown, I always make it a habit of getting myself a crepe here. On occasion, I sometimes make a trek to japantown to just eat a crepe.

The crepe is thin and tastes decent (not thick and gross like other crepe places I've been to). Paired with ice cream and some sweet fruit, it's euphoria! I always get their combo fruit/ice cream crepe. Make sure you get sweet fruit or your crepe experience will be dampened by the tartness of some fruits (strawberry, kiwi, etc). I like the banana, chocolate, whipped cream, ice cream combo. About $6-7.

This place is quite popular with the youth. Sometimes there is a line, but the wait is worth it. Remember that it's CASH ONLY. You can watch them make your crepe which is always fun to do while you wait for your crepe cone.
author: Cookie Monster Z.

description:
When in J-town in the afternoon, where else could you go for a satisfying snack?  Sophie's Crepe is definitely your destination...  Inside seating is limited and it is rather stuffy.  So, you will end up eating at the seating area in the mall.  

Different offerings are wrapped up in these deliciously great crepes.  Offerings range from nutella and fruits to ice cream.  If you have something very specific in mind, they can cater to you without a problem.  I always go for the crepe with green tea gelato, red been paste, and macha sauce.  It takes some special skills to eat it but practice makes perfect.  So enjoy the ice cream crepe eating journey!
author: Ginni S.

description:
Green tea ice cream and red bean paste.. the best.  I love sweet crepes but rarely eat them.  But, the minute you step into the shopping center, the sweet aroma gets you (well it always does for me).  I make a bee-line for the stairs and see the workers at Sophie's creating perfection.  I don't understand salty crepes like ham, cheese, mayo, and eggs.. WHY ruin it?!!!!  Just doesn't sound tempting to me. Might as well eat a sandwich if you're going to order that crap.  

Another favorite is the banana, nutella, vanilla ice cream, and whip cream.
author: anita h.

description:
I just happened to spot the place when one of my Japanese friends took me to Japantown since I had never been there. When I saw it, I had to try it due to the hypes and raves about the place. I'm always a fan of crepes and I must say that this place has good sweet crepes! Love them.. so good and the price is decent, too. I got the strawberry, whipped cream, and chocolate syrup ($4.95). YUUMMM!!! 

The place was kind of empty since we went there around 2 pm. I need to come again and try the savory crepes. But, I hope this time around, the crepes maker would be friendlier!
author: Daisy S.

description:
I call this place LIFE CHANGING. Eat a crepe, CHANGE YO LIFE. I always get the gelato filled ones, and while the gelato Sophie's serves is especially nice, what really makes a difference is the crepe they produce. Slightly crunchy but tender, all wound up in a handy cone shape for consumption, it's a marvel of engineering. 

I'll never find a crepe this amazing again in my life, I've resigned to the fact.
author: Kat C.

description:
Delicious. We waited twenty minutes for our Crepes and I felt that was too long of a wait to warrant a 5 star rating.
I ordered a strawberry, banana, nutella and whip cream cream. Hubby had vanilla ice cream and whip cream. The crepe was crisp, tasty and light. It was also stuffed in a little paper crepe holder. Very smart.
author: Joie G.

description:
I came here right after lunch at Juban (I usually like to eat something sweet after a good meal). I figured it had to be good because everyone in the mall was eating one. This was the first time I've seen a crepe wrapped up in a cone shape. I'm use to getting it folded on a plate but I have to admit that the cone shaped allowed me to eat on the go. I had the nutella and kiwi. I'm simple....I think nutella with anything is good.

Definitely recommend if your in vacinity.
author: David W.

description:
I've always liked Sophie's Crepes. I used to go there pretty often, whether for one of their delicious "lunch" crepes (turkey and cheddar equals yum) or for a scrumptious dessert crepe - the Japan crepe is awesome. The menu isn't all that extensive, but it has some variety there for those that are picky. Mostly their choices range from fruits (strawberry, banana) and sandwich ingredients (meats, cheese, etc.) to gelato and Nutella. Good stuff to be sure.

One thing I don't like about their menu - and it's the big thing that keeps me from giving Sophie's a full five stars - is that some of the extras cost way more than they should. For example, while the Japan crepe is around $4.50 (give or take a few cents), the Japan Special, which adds whipped cream, is almost a whole dollar more. Uh, why? Not only do the extras tend to cost more than they should, but they're usually not very generous with them either. Heck, sometimes they're like that with the regular ingredients too, and when you're paying about $4-$5 for an already thin crepe it just dampens the whole deal.

Atmosphere-wise everything is great. Though Sophie's is a tiny place with only three tables inside, there's lots of seating right outside next to Kinokuniya Bookstore. You can also watch the people making the crepes from the large window outside, which is usually what a lot of people and tourists tend to do. The service has never been much of a bother either, so kudos to them for that.

All in all Sophie's is one of those places you just have to try at least once, especially if you're in the area. It's one of the few highlights in Japantown that has actually outlasted many other businesses - the Japantown Denny's, the old bowling alley, Mikado Music, and such. Definitely well worth it.
author: Will C.

description: First time eating here. I had the Kiwi & Nutella Crepe--not bad. First time having a crepe like a cone. A little conservative on the fillings, but overall a great evening snack. Oh, and no photos of the staff making the crepes--even though they are making them in front of the window for everyone to watch...I took a photo anyways...
author: Colin P.

description: When the cashier made a mistake, they wouldn't refund or else I would've rated it 5 out of 5!!!!:-( they asked me to charge at first. that was wat the cashier said!!!!
author: Mikey N.

description: I used to love this place, but they r just not  that delicious anymore and they touch ur food wit bare hand after touching many other things..
author: Jenni C.

description: Extra crispy and unappetizing looking crepes. Avoid.
author: Sarah S.

description: I happened to be in JapanTown several weeks ago so I decide to give this place a try. The place was pretty busy on weekends so expected to wait a bit. The cashier was very knowledgable about the menu and she answered all my questions clearly. I ended up ordering a strawberry and nutella crepe and the taste was amazing! Definitely the best crepe I have ever tried! I also noticed many people ordered crepes with ice cream so I will try that next time. I liked that you can easily carry the crepe with you and walk around (because of the limited seating inside the store and number of people waiting to order, you are not likley to enjoy sitting there anyway. You will be better off sitting outside the store with better air circulation). You won't be disppointed!
author: Sakura K.

description: While I'm not much into crepes aside from Banh Xeo (if that even qualifies as a crepe), I got to admit that the "Japanese" crepe they have here is pretty good. Nothing beats a warm and fluffy dough w/ green tea ice cream and red bean filling. Heck, it was the aroma that drew my wife and I here after having a quick lunch at "On the Bridge." Only drawback was they kinda skimp on the filling...they hardly put any red bean paste on ours :(.
author: K L.

description: $6.57 for a crepe with Nutella, strawberries, and vanilla ice cream.  Long line, about 20 min wait.  Really good though.  They do crank them out!  4 1/2 stars.
author: Joe M.

description:
I come here each time i'm down in SF.  Great deals - fav is the nutella w/ fresh strawberries whip cream and vanilla ice cream.  Under $6 - DEAL!
No photos allowed inside w/ little seating. They got the whole order pay and watch your food be made thing down pretty well.  
The actual crepe holder is what won me over; it's sturdy and keeps all the crap off your hands - score!  the crepe in itself is pretty freakin good too; not too sweet and cooked just right w/ slightly crunchy edges.  Perfection!
author: Myra R.

description: I ordered the mandarin orange and whipped cream crepe, while my friend ordered the mixed fruit (kiwi, strawberry, and banana) with whipped cream.   Both were super yummy!!   Can't wait to go back and try some more.
author: Saskia B.

description: This place has been around for a quite a long time and thank goodness for that because their crepes are so good! What's there not to love about crepes? Crispy crepe shaped into a cone filled with ice cream and your favorite fruit and toppings...delicious! My favorite is the Mandarin orange with vanilla ice cream. It's a perfect summertime treat. Yum!
author: Tracy Y.

description:
Love the place, not to many places prepare your food right in front of you. I mean, you can see the process of what they are doing to your food right in front of you. So, I guess if you complain abou their crepes they can not spit in it when you return them back to the kitchen. 

Been there for so many time and never fail me. So 5 star for the crepes. I think it's under $5 for one crepes. 

Note: if you're going to see a concert at the Fillmore, this place is a nice place for a date. Walk around the shopping mall and have some crepes before the concert or after dinner can set the night on firer.....
author: Chris S.

description: OMG!  I knew I wanted to eat here when I was researching SanFran eats.  And I was not disappointed!  Though I wasn't even hungry, I just had to have a mixed fruit w/ Nutella and whipped cream crepe.  Soooo good!  The crepes are perfect...not too thin or thick.  My husband is not that crazy about Nutella and at first didn't even want to try any, but after all my "ooohhh" and "aaaahhh" he finally took a bite and loved it!  We inhaled the entire thing and it was awesome.  I'll come back next time I'm in town.  Only draw back - cash only.
author: Thuyanh P.

description: There are 2 Japanese crepe shops in Japan town. This one is a little bit more expensive than the other one. Still I love the crepe here, so many variety. You can mix anything and create your own crepe, or get the one that already in the menu. Everything is yummy!!!!!!
author: Suvida N.

description: My friend had raved about Sophies and told me I had to go there on this past trip to SF.  So my fiance and I headed to Sophies and saw a fairly long line - this usually is an indicator that the food is good.  I had been craving a crepe for the longest and my usual choice is a nutella crepe, but I thought that I might as well try something that's not normally offered in San Diego so I ordered the Japanese crepe - green tea ice cream with red beans.  My fiance ordered the nutella and banana crepe.  The size of the crepe was rather large - that deserves a star.  The crepes were crispy - that deserves a star.  The prices were decent - another star.  and the flavor was enjoyable - another star.  My fiance said he'd give it 4 1/2 stars as he expected more filling inside...  Definitely worth the visit and for future trips, I will mark this in my itinerary :)
author: Allison J.

description: Love the crepes here. Every time I get to go to San Francisco, I have to drop by. There's always a line whenever I go but worth the wait in line.
author: Frank Z.

description:
This place ain't gourmet food, but it's awesome for a fun and delicious portable dessert.

I invariably order a fresh fruit and nutella dessert crepe. They wrap it up in a paper cone for you so it's totally portable, and you don't need any utensils to eat it. The crepe style is thin and on the edge of crispy, and they're generous with the fillings.

It's a little pricy and on weekends there's a huge line, but it's still a favorite Japantown mall dessert for me.
author: Andrew H.

description:
***Mandarin oranges and vanilla ice cream ***
Sophie's always puts me over the top, since I always end up here after eating lunch or dinner.  It's location couldn't be better since some of my favorite places are on that same side of J-town center, like Kinokuniya Bookstore and Kinokuniya Stationery & Gift.  
There are a handful of tables inside with a large window overlooking Geary St.  and there are a few benches out in the plaza that allow for ample people watching.
author: Clay K.

description:
I have yet made my return to this famous crepe place. It brought memories back for sure - good and bad. This crepe place is real awesome and very delicious too!

It does get packed but only because they know how to make a real tasty crepe. I always get a dessert crepe and it is damn good! 

Price is not bad at all and you will enjoy yourself with whatever you choose to get. 

Strawberry crepe with Nutella and ice cream is my way to go.
author: Jay C.

description: This is, in my oppinion, the best place to get a sweet crepe in the bay area. Most other places have chewy crepes skimp on the toppings, but not here. Crispy crepes stuffed with awesomeness. The gelatos are great, and the crepes with fresh fruit are my personal favorite. They're cash only, so be sure to have some with you or you'll have to use their ATM and get charged a couple bucks. And speaking of cash, they are a bit on the expensive side, but totally worth it. One of the nicest things about them is that the crepes are wrapped in paper in a style reminiscent of an ice cream cone so you can take them with you as you enjoy the rest of Japantown.
author: Chase C.

description: Whether you actually order a crepe or not, the intoxicating aroma of them coming off the pan is scrumptious. Wandered down here after stuffing myself at my local sushi boat last night and deliciously topped off the evening with some perfect green tea gelato. One of these days I'll try one of their handheld ice cream-in-a-crepe concoctions, but for now I'm just a scent hustler.
author: Gregor G.

description: Ordered 3 fairly simple dessert crepes with 1 or 2 ingredients which came to almost $14.  Skimpy on the filling.  I didn't think the crepe tasted like much either and was cold.  Over rated, over priced.  I would have rather spent that amount elsewhere---and it's cash only---
author: T. W.

description:
There are very few foods I would eat even when I'm stuffed and this is one of them. I've been here several times and I always want to come back the next day for more. The Japanese crepe is my favorite. The crepe is perfect--crispy on the edges, soft in the middle, with a nice subtly buttery bite. The green tea gelato is not to sweet and it complements the red bean paste very well. 

I will be definitely going back and if you like crepes, you don't want to miss this place! :)
author: Sandy S.

description: I don't know Sophie but what I do know is that her crepes are pretty darn good. I tried the turkey, tomato, and avocado hot crepe and it was probably the best crepe sandwich I've eaten- also the first and last. I'll definitely be back next time I'm getting a haircut at this shopping plaza.
author: Lou T.

description: The big crowd is usually here for the crepe which ate a hit. I am in the minority in that I come for the sorbet ice cream which I feel are fantastic also.
author: H K.

description:
The strawberry, ice cream, chocolate syrup and whipped cream crepe is yummy as an incredible indulgence that you can enjoy even before consuming...because it is made right in front of your eyes! Fast fast fast. Faster than Ti Couz and an even yummier dessert than the one I ordered from Ti Couz.

Plenty of other customers are repeat visitors. Just ask them!
author: miriam b.

description:
Favourite guilty pleasure.
Redbean paste, vanilla bean gelato in a crepe.  
Perfect any time, all the time.
author: M E.

description:
Awesomest green tea crepe I've ever ever had. The batter they use is on the sweeter side and the heat pan they use thins out the the crepe so much that it's crispy and golden when done. The crunchy crisps and the ton of fillings (be it fruits, jams, sauces, or icecream), it's bound to be a load of deliciousness. 

I haven't tried their drinks yet though. That'll be next.
author: Joey W.

description:
I love their crepes. I usually get the dessert crepe with strawberry, nutella and vanilla ice cream. It's yummy! They give a decent amount of filling. During peak times the wait for the crepe is long. Create-your-own crepes can get expensive so I usually go with the pre-designed creations on the board. The wait for the crepe order is long, but watching the guy making the crepes is entertaining. He has a quick hand. There are a few benches outside the store to sit and enjoy your delicious crepe. I give 2 thumbs up for this refreshing dessert for those rare hot days in the city.  

I had a craving and was in Japantown but they were closed Monday. I was disappointed.
author: Candace F.

description:
nom nom nom... I love this place!

There are two crepe places in the same building, but I decided on this place since it was next to the bookstore and there was a huge line, meaning it had to be good! 

I ordered the mix fruit crepe at $4.95, which I've had before at a Q-cup for around the same price, but I must say, this one beats out Q-cup any day.

The crepe is crispy and light, the fruits were fresh and the vanilla ice cream is very tasty! I am so hankering for another!

Oh and try their root beer floats! They were $2.95 each, but oh so yummy!
author: Amy A.

description: Tucked away in a corner in Japan town, Sophie's Choice - er, I mean Sophie's Crepes is quite a pleasant surprise. The crepes are made fresh in front of you and they are pretty good. I had a banana, strawberry, and chocolate crepe, which really hit the right notes on my sweet tooth at the time, but frankly it wasn't the freshest fruit. Also, they could use a little more diversity and creativity in their menu, though I believe this is a Japanese chain so I can't say I'm too surprised by the plain-vanilla choice. Regardless, the crepe was pretty good, I would definitely come here again if I were in the area, but the Saint-Germaine truck in SoMa remains to be the best.
author: Tian X.

description: Great, wonderful crepes. Gotta love the price. I wish the lines were not so crazy, but after FINALLY eating it, i understand why.  yummm...... (strawberry and chocolate)
author: Giggly C.

description: Yum, tasty crepes. I tried the "Japanese" crepe, which included green tea ice cream and red bean paste. They definitely get points for uniqueness. They make their crepes crunchier than elsewhere, which I think is a good thing. Looking forward to trying one of their savory crepes next time.
author: Adam B.

description: I got the fruit and whipped cream crepe. A bit hard to eat, but very tasty and the crepe was awesome.
author: Anne D.

description:
yeah, this place is pricey, but after staring at the perfectionist minded crepe making guy behind the counter, i am totally convinced that he really wants to make sure that the stuff that comes out is the best possible result.  he scrapped four different ones because they weren't perfectly filled!!

so, basically, no crepe comes out unless it is perfectly round and without any blemishes [i.e. holes, wrinkles, tears, etc.].

the stuff still as yummy as ever.
author: Karen T.

description: I went to Sophie's today again and tried a #14 (mixed fruit with nutella).  Don't get my four-stars wrong, it was really good but it's rather pricey compared to other places like Genki's, which I tried immediately after Sophie's.  So I reduced my original rating by one star.  Sorry Sophie.  There's someone else - Genki.  Guess our love affair may not last forever.
author: Linh V.

description: This place was great!  Although a little small inside and could get crowded....the crepes were pretty good!  Comparable to Genki Crepes!!  Even if you don't find seating inside, there's plenty of seating just outside of it.  And the prices are decent.  Will come back again when we're in the area!
author: S U.

description: I have a weakness for the unique combination of crepes, whipped cream, green tea ice cream, azuki beans and matcha sauce. Given that there really aren't that many places in SF that offer this Asian-inspired treat, Sophie's Crepes satisfies whenever a craving hits.
author: Liz H.

description: I hate to wait in line but I have to only because their crepes look just so yummy.  I'm eager to try it largely due to the tempting look of their crepes, especially the one with strawberry, kiwi, banana and whipped cream.  Love the fresh taste. I kind of wished they had a smaller size available since I just finished lunch in the next door restaurant. Way too much for a dessert. You can imagine how stuffed I was after wolfing it down.  So much for my stomach. I took 1 star out for the waiting and cash only.
author: Zebra G.

description: Delicious............................a really good job of getting through the long lines during the busy times. The crepes are some of the better ones I've eaten. have a good variety and priced fairly. I will say that it can feel really crowded and it does make it hard to be clean. There is a parking lot nearby so thats not to bad.
author: Keisha S.

description: I had the vanilla ice cream with whipped cream, nutella and strawberries.  It was very good, although it was nothing special.  This was the first time I had crepes that were served in a cone like shape.  I was having difficulty eating it so i just ripped the cone and ate it.  I would probably go back and try another crepe from their menu...
author: RJ B.

description: Hands down the best crepes in Japantown.  The Japanese one with red  bean paste and green tea ice cream is my favorite.  =)  Definitely save room in your belly for a crepe after eating in J-town (which I know can be hard to do!)
author: Maxine S.

description:
Awesome crepes. They're not stingy with the filling, and their batter doesn't have this weird taste like some of the other crepe places I've been to. Their gelato is surprisingly good too. 

Only downside is I think they're a bit pricey. But then again, each crepe is sort of a meal onto itself.
author: Wing G.

description:
I think my sweetie and I almost got into a fight over our shared crepe...oh heaven green tea ice cream, redbean, and uh...oh so much wonderfulness in the # 17 or 18 with additional bananas.
Seriously though... it was all passive/aggressive-like, each of us turning our head and sneaking an extra bite before handing it back to the other.  When we finished we both exclaimed that we felt like we didn't eat much of it, or in other unspoken words "you ate the whole thing, you greedy pig!"
So really, nobody is kidding here, get your own crepe when you go to Sophie's, and get it with ic/gelato for sure!
author: miranda caroligne ..

description:
This place rocks! Once you step inside Sophie's you will smell the wonderful scent of crepes in the making Mmm lol The crepes are so delicious, so it's worth a little wait to get it. You can see the employess make your crepe if want while you wait, and it looks cool the way they do it lol. 

I like Crepe 'E' on the menu. It has starwberries,vanilla ice cream, choco syrup and whipped cream. Yummy! 

Definitely buy your crepes here pplz!
author: Liz V.

description:
YUM!  Japan....thank you.  I had the banana, nutella and ice cream combo.  Had to wait for just a little bit, but boy was this satisfying.  This really quenched my banana and chocolate craving I had been experiencing lately.  

Some people felt that this was a bit pricey, but you get a LARGE desert for like $5.  Not bad I say, better than a slice of cake which goes for the same at lots of restaurants.  Plus, you get ice cream + pastry (of sorts) + mobility (carry this sucker around and walk about Jtown).
author: Cat R.

description:
Sophie's is the first place I ever had a crepe.  I was young and I remember waiting forever just to get one.  I've been hooked ever since I had my first bite of nutella with banana.  Now that I live in the south bay though, it's hard to get my hands on crepes which taste anything like Sophie's.

Every time I go up to San Francisco, I go to Japantown and grab a bite from this place.  I love the crepes here and you can watch them make the batter, pour it on the pan-thing and then put on the rather large amount of toppings before handing it to you with a napkin.

Only problem is the wait when it gets crowded, but it's well worth it.
author: Bobby Y.

description: Best crepe I ever had. If only I lived in SF...which will never ever happen. I was in the city dining with some friends and they treated me to a crepe afterwards. I had the strawberry and nutella. OMG. YUMMMMMM. I want one right now.
author: Stephanie R.

description: Good tasting crepes. Price is kinda expensive for a desert but they really fill you up. If you are visiting japan town, you have to check this place out. I recommend to get a fruit and nutella crepe since they use combine nutella, whip cream, and fresh fruit quite nicely. Very satisfying desert of snack.
author: Robert Y.

description:
I've made long journeys to this place, and always leave both satisfied and smiling.  I've probably eaten the #17 Japanese style crepe a hundred times, literally... and few things in this world can top its perfection.  Green tea gelato, maccha sauce, and red bean paste... all fresh, all heavenly.  There's almost always a long line, but it's always worth the wait.

Fresh ingredients, gelato, and the amazing wafts of crepes-a-cookin' make for one of my favorite dessert places in all of San Francisco... and being that I live in the Peninsula, the frequency of my visits should speak to how much it's worth checking out.  Go make your taste buds happy; try anything on their menu.

- Chris
author: Chris K.

description: This is by far the best crepe place that I've been to. We ordered strawberries, bananas & nutella with a scoop of vanilla bean ice cream and could not stop eating it even though we had just had a huge dinner. The crepe is cooked to a perfect golden crisp so that it's crunchy on the sides and soft and chewy within. The ingredients are fresh and the added option of ice cream/gelato is welcomed by the tastebuds (not so much the waistline). The only annoying thing is that the production time can be quite long and it's always way too poppin on weekends.
author: Lilian W.

description: They're usually pretty busy. This is great for after a movie or after dinner even. I love stopping by to try a different dessert crepe each time. it just reminds me of one of those simple pleasures in life. =)
author: Tiff W.

description: Delicious!  I love this lighter style of crepe too vs the heavier stuff from Crepevine and Crepe's on Cole.  I was really looking for a breakfast crepe with eggs though and these folks do not have eggs, just cold egg salad.  It was OK, but I wouldn't recommend this place for breakfast.  The dessert crepes are delicious though, great for evenings out.
author: Daniel H.

description: Maybe it's because I like the French style of crepes better that I am only giving this place 3 stars.  This style of crepe just doesn't do it for me.  I don't get what the point is of paying all that money for a dry crepe with ice cream inside.  They did a very yummy sundae though with green tea gelato, red bean paste, and (store bought) whipped cream.  But for $6?!  It wasn't THAT good.  It's ice cream and bean paste for god's sake.
author: Kandi K.

description:
If you want the worlds best crepe...go to Sophie's Crepes. I don't know what they do...but it is good. The crepe itself is crispy and flaky and sweet! Not soggy thick and wet like so many other crepe places. I have yet found one as good as Sophie's...you go girl!

Oh yeah, the price is about 6 bucks...it's worth it!
author: Poppy C.

description:
I like this crepe place better than most others, probably mostly due to its convenient cone-shaped packaging.  ...you can eat and walk at the same time, no knives or forks needed.  Price is cheap, selection's pretty good.  They make the crepe first, then put the filling in separate - they don't cook it all together on the crepe pan like most other places...

...which means, I can enjoy my veggie of lettuce, sprouts, tomato, avocado and mayonnaise without the mayo getting all hot and nasty.

Mmmmm.
author: D. L.

description:
I had my first crepe here... and it was All-right.... i mean there is probably better tasting crepe out there.. This place is not expensive but its not cheap.. So if your in Jtown and your craving some crepes.. just go to sophies crepes!

-x3 shells
author: Lily X.

description:
this place definitely has a lot of delicious crepes! the crepes are thin and crunchy. 

though i think the biggest downfall is the whip cream. ITS SO THICK! its one of those kinds you can get for restaurant to supply mass quantities of whip cream. i wish they made their own! it would be much lighter, and definitely not make me want to cringe at ever bite as my calories quadruple. 

the ice cream was REALLY yummy. the strawberries were fresh and sweet. they give you pretty good portions here.
author: Linda L.

description: BEST CREPE EVERR!. everytime i go with my friends we always complain about the lines always being sooo long but when we finally get the crepe its well worth the wait. i suggest when u order ur crepe u get it along with either green tea, vanilla or black sesame ice cream.
author: sylviawon w.

description: oh..my..god.  Best crepes I've ever had. Very light and thin, not soggy and conveniently packaged for ease of consumption!  Order the crepes with strawberries - huge, ripe slices that were likely bathed in sugar beforehand.  Also added nutella to mine - a staple for crepes.
